security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate image processing toolkit that creates animated GIFs. It uses standard libraries (PIL, numpy, imageio) for local image manipulation only. No network calls, no credential access, no code execution vulnerabilities.

content.user_title: Create Slack GIFs with Animation Templates
content.value_statement: Creating animated GIFs for Slack requires meeting strict file size limits and using specific animation styles. This toolkit provides validators to check your GIFs meet Slack requirements and composable animation primitives like bounce, shake, pulse, and spin to create engaging animations.
actual_capabilities: Create animated GIFs with composable animation primitives (bounce, shake, pulse, spin, fade, zoom, explode, and more)
Validate GIFs against Slack size limits (64KB for emoji GIFs, 2MB for message GIFs)
Optimize GIFs with color quantization, frame deduplication, and resizing for emoji size limits
Add visual effects like particles, impact flashes, motion blur, and screen shake
Apply easing functions for natural motion (bounce, elastic, back, and smooth animations)
Use pre-built color palettes and typography tools for professional-looking GIFs
limitations: Does not convert existing videos or images to GIF (only programmatic creation)
Emoji rendering depends on system emoji fonts (best on macOS, limited elsewhere)
Cannot upload GIFs directly to Slack (generates files for manual upload)
Creating complex animations requires Python programming knowledge

output_examples.input: Create a bouncing animation with a soccer ball emoji, 30 frames at 20fps, save as goal.gif with 64 colors
output: Added soccer ball emoji at starting position
Applied ease_out_bounce easing for realistic bounce
Saved goal.gif: 480x480, 30 frames, 20 fps, 1.5s duration, 48 colors
Validated: 32.4 KB - within 2MB Slack limit for message GIFs

best_practices: Test file size frequently during development using check_slack_size() to stay under limits
Use 128x128 dimensions and 32-48 colors for emoji GIFs to reliably stay under 64KB
Combine animation primitives creatively but test performance at target dimensions
anti_patterns: Do not ignore size warnings - emoji GIFs over 64KB will fail to upload
Do not use gradients or complex effects that increase file size unnecessarily
Do not exceed 12-15 frames for emoji GIFs - fewer frames means smaller files

faq.question: What tools is this compatible with?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Claude Code, and Codex for generating GIFs programmatically

faq.question: What are the Slack GIF limits?
faq.answer: Emoji GIFs must be under 64KB at 128x128px. Message GIFs must be under 2MB with 480x480px optimal

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing code?
faq.answer: Import the modules you need, create frames using animation functions, then use GIFBuilder to assemble and save

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. All processing is local using standard image libraries. No data is sent anywhere

faq.question: Why is my GIF too large?
faq.answer: Reduce frames, colors, or dimensions. For emoji GIFs, use optimize_for_emoji=True and 32-48 colors

faq.question: How does this compare to online GIF makers?
faq.answer: This toolkit provides programmatic control and Slack-specific optimization not available in online tools
